doc.title: FASTA
doc.reference: Pearson, W. R. (1999) Flexible sequence similarity searching with the FASTA3 program package. Methods in Molecular Biology
W. R. Pearson and D. J. Lipman (1988), Improved Tools for Biological Sequence Analysis, PNAS 85:2444-2448
W. R. Pearson (1998) Empirical statistical estimates for sequence similarity searches. In J. Mol. Biol. 276:71-84
Pearson, W. R. (1996) Effective protein sequence comparison. In Meth. Enz., R. F. Doolittle, ed. (San Diego: Academic Press) 266:227-258

interface.label:
Fasta program?
Choose a program fasta (protein or nucleotide query vs similar db ) tfasta (protein query vs translated nucleic db) fastx (translated nucleotide query vs protein db (frameshifts only only between codons)) tfastx (protein query vs translated DNA db (frameshifts only between codons)) fasty (fastx + frameshifts anywhere) tfasty (tfastx + frameshifts anywhere) fastf (mixed peptide seq vs protein db (modified algorithm)) tfastf (mixed peptide seq vs translated DNA db (modified algorithm)) fasts (several short peptide seq vs protein db (modified algorithm)) tfasts (several short peptide seq vs translated DNA db (modified algorithm))
- fasta: scan a protein or DNA sequence library for similar sequences
- tfasta: compare a protein sequence to a DNA sequence librarSy, translating the DNA sequence library `on-the-fly' to the 3 forward and the 3 reverse frames without frameshifts.
- fastx/fasty: compare a DNA sequence to a protein sequence database, comparing the translated DNA sequence in three frames, with frameshifts. fasty2 allows frameshifts inside codons.
- tfastx/tfasty: compare a protein sequence vs a translated DNA db, with frameshifts. tfasty allows frameshifts inside codons.
- fastf/tfastf: compare an ordered peptide mixture (obtained for example by Edman degradation of a CNBr cleavage) against a protein or translated DNA database.
- fasts/tfasts: compare a set of short peptide fragments (obtained from a mass-spec analysis of a protein) against a protein or translated DNA database.
Is it a DNA or protein sequence (-n) Choose a biotype DNA Protein

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Protein Database?
Choose a database Select Alu repeats from REPBASE nrprot: NCBI non-redundant Genbank CDS translations+PDB+Swissprot+PIR Protein Data Bank NCBI Reference Sequence (RefSeq) Database last release NCBI Reference Sequence (RefSeq) updates RefSeq (last release + updates) sbase: annotated domains sequences uniprot: Universal Protein Resource (sprot+treml) uniprot_sprot: Universal Protein Resource (SwissProt part) uniprot_trembl: Universal Protein Resource (TrEmbl part) Clustered sets of sequences from UniProt Knowledgebase (UniRef 90) Clustered sets of sequences from UniProt Knowledgebase (UniRef 50) Virus Pathogen Resource Genbank : Whole Genome Shotgun
Choose a protein db for fasta, fastx, fatsf, fasty or fasts.
Please note that Swissprot usage by and for commercial entities requires a license agreement.

Choose a nucleotide db for fasta, tfasta, tfastx, tfasty, tfastf or tfasts

Break long library sequences into blocks (-N)?
Break long library sequences into blocks of N residues. Useful for bacterial genomes, which have only one sequence entry. -N 2000 works well for well for bacterial genomes.

Sensitivity and speed of the search ?
ktup sets the sensitivity and speed of the search. If ktup=2, similar regions in the two sequences being compared are found by looking at pairs of aligned residues; if ktup=1, single aligned amino acids are examined. ktup can be set to 2 or 1 for protein sequences, or from 1 to 6 for DNA sequences. The default if ktup is not specified is 2 for proteins and 6 for DNA. 1ktup=1 should be used for oligonucleotides (DNA query length < 20).

Threshold for band optimization (FASTA, FASTX). (-c)?
The threshold value is normally calculated based on sequence length.

Penalty for opening a gap (-f)?
The default for fasta with proteins is -12 and -16 for DNA
The default for fastx/fasty/tfastz/tfasty is -15.

Penalty for gap extension (-g)?
The default for fasta is -2 for proteins and -4 for DNA
The default for fastx/fasty/tfastz/tfasty is -3.

Maximal expectation value threshold for displaying scores and alignments (-E)?
Expectation value limit for displaying scores and alignments. Defaults are 10.0 for FASTA protein searches, 5.0 for translated DNA/protein comparisons, and 2.0 for DNA/DNA searches.

Minimal expectation value threshold for displaying scores and alignments (-F)?
Expectation value lower limit for score and alignment display. If value is 1e-6 prevents library sequences with E()-values lower than 1e-6 from being displayed. This allows the use to focus on more distant relationships.
This allow one to skip over close relationships in searches for more distant relationships.
Maximum positive value for a nucleotid match (-r)

Maximum negative penalty value for a nucleotid mismatch (-r)?
'+5/-4' are the default values for nucleotid match/mismatch, but '+3/-2' can perform better in some cases.
Scoring matrix file (-s) BLOSUM50 BLOSUM62 BLOSUM80 PAM20 PAM40 PAM120 PAM250 MDM_10 MDM_20 MDM_40

Penalty for a match to 'X' (independently of the PAM matrix) (-x)?
Particularly useful for fast[xy], where termination codons are encoded as 'X'.
Penalty for frameshift between two codons (fast[xy]/tfast[xy]) (-h)
Penalty for frameshift within a codon (fasty/tfasty) (-j)
Search only the three forward frames (-3) Yes No
Reverse complement the query sequence (-i) Yes No

Use genetic code for translation (tfasta/tfast[xy]/fast[xy]) (-t) Standard (1) Vertebrate Mitochondrial (1) Yeast Mitochondrial (2) Mold, Protozoan, Coelenterate Mitochondrial and Mycoplasma/Spiroplasma (3) Invertebrate Mitochondrial (4) Ciliate Macronuclear and Dasycladacean (5) Echinoderm Mitochondrial (6) Euplotid Nuclear (7) Bacterial (8) Alternative Yeast Nuclear (9) Ascidian Mitochondrial (10) Flatworm Mitochondrial (11) Blepharisma Macronuclear (12)

Band-width used for optimization (-y)?
Set the band-width used for optimization. -y 16 is the default for protein when ktup=2 and for all DNA alignments. -y 32 is used for protein and ktup=1. For proteins, optimization slows comparison 2-fold and is highly recommended.

Force Smith-Waterman alignment for DNA (-A)?
Yes No
Force Smith-Waterman alignment for output. Smith-Waterman is the default for protein sequences and FASTX, but not for TFASTA or DNA comparisons with FASTA.

Turn fasta band optimization off during initial phase (-o)?
Yes No
Turn off default optimization of all scores greater than OPTCUT. Shirt results by 'initn' scores reduces the accuracy of statistical estimates. This was the behavior of fasta1 versions.

Specify statistical calculation. (-z)?
Turn off statistics (0) Weigthed regression against the length of the library sequence (1) Maximum likelihood estimates of Lambda abd K (2) Altschul-Gishas statistical (3) Alternate regression method: Variation 1 of 1 (4) Alternate regression method: Variation 2 of 1 (5) Maximum likelihood estimate based on the method of Mott (6)
In general, 1 and 2 are the best methods.

Estimate statistical parameters from shuffled copies of each library sequence (-z)?
Yes No
This doubles the time required for a search, but allows accurate statistics to be estimated for libraries comprised of a single protein family.
Turn off histogram display (-H) Yes No
Number of similarity scores to be shown (-b)
Number of alignments to be shown (-d)
HTML output (-m) Yes No

Alternate display of matches and mismatches in alignments (-m)?
0 [: identities] [. conservative repl] [ non-conserv repl] 1: [ identities] [x conservative repl] [X non-conserv repl] 2: [. identities] [res mismatch] - don't display the 2nd seq 3: writes a file of library sequences in FASTA format 4: displays a graph of the alignment 9: 0 + percent identity + coordinates 10: output more information
(MARKX) =0,1,2,3,4. Alternate display of matches and mismatches in alignments.
MARKX=0 uses ':','.',' ', for identities, conservative replacements, and non-conservative replacements, respectively.
MARKX=1 uses ' ','x', and 'X'.
MARKX=2 does not show the second sequence, but uses the second alignment line to display matches with a '.' for identity, or with the mismatched residue for mismatches. MARKX=2 is useful for aligning large numbers of similar sequences.
MARKX=3 writes out a file of library sequences in FASTA format. MARKX=3 should always be used with the 'SHOWALL' (-a) option, but this does not completely ensure that all of the sequences output will be aligned.
MARKX=4 displays a graph of the alignment of the library sequence with respect to the query sequence, so that one can identify the regions of the query sequence that are conserved.
Sequences ranked by the z-score based on the init1 score (-1) Yes No
Show normalize score as (-B) z-score (1) bit-score (0)
Output line length for sequence alignments (-w)

Start numbering the aligned sequences at position x1 x2 (2 numbers separated by comma) (-X)?
Causes fasta/lfasta/plfasta to start numbering the aligned sequences starting with offset1 and offset2, rather than 1 and 1. This is particularly useful for showing alignments of promoter regions.
Display more information about the library sequence in the alignment (-L) Yes No

Lower case filtering (-S)?
Yes No
Treat lower-case characters in the query or library sequence as 'low-complexity' residues. These characters are treated as 'X' during the initial scan, but are treated as normal residues during the final alignment. Sinces statistical significance is calculated from similarity score calculated during library search, low complexity regions will not produce statistical significant matches.
If a significant alignment contains low complexity regions the final score may be higher than the score obtained during the search.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: - fasta: scan a protein or DNA sequence library for similar sequences
- tfasta: compare a protein sequence to a DNA sequence librarSy, translating the DNA sequence library `on-the-fly' to the 3 forward and the 3 reverse frames without frameshifts.
- fastx/fasty: compare a DNA sequence to a protein sequence database, comparing the translated DNA sequence in three frames, with frameshifts. fasty2 allows frameshifts inside codons.
- tfastx/tfasty: compare a protein sequence vs a translated DNA db, with frameshifts. tfasty allows frameshifts inside codons.
- fastf/tfastf: compare an ordered peptide mixture (obtained for example by Edman degradation of a CNBr cleavage) against a protein or translated DNA database.
- fasts/tfasts: compare a set of short peptide fragments (obtained from a mass-spec analysis of a protein) against a protein or translated DNA database.

Please note that Swissprot usage by and for commercial entities requires a license agreement.

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Choose a nucleotide db for fasta, tfasta, tfastx, tfasty, tfastf or tfasts
Break long library sequences into blocks of N residues. Useful for bacterial genomes, which have only one sequence entry. -N 2000 works well for well for bacterial genomes.

ktup sets the sensitivity and speed of the search. If ktup=2, similar regions in the two sequences being compared are found by looking at pairs of aligned residues; if ktup=1, single aligned amino acids are examined. ktup can be set to 2 or 1 for protein sequences, or from 1 to 6 for DNA sequences. The default if ktup is not specified is 2 for proteins and 6 for DNA. 1ktup=1 should be used for oligonucleotides (DNA query length < 20).
The threshold value is normally calculated based on sequence length.
The default for fasta with proteins is -12 and -16 for DNA
The default for fastx/fasty/tfastz/tfasty is -15.
The default for fasta is -2 for proteins and -4 for DNA
The default for fastx/fasty/tfastz/tfasty is -3.
Expectation value limit for displaying scores and alignments. Defaults are 10.0 for FASTA protein searches, 5.0 for translated DNA/protein comparisons, and 2.0 for DNA/DNA searches.

Expectation value lower limit for score and alignment display. If value is 1e-6 prevents library sequences with E()-values lower than 1e-6 from being displayed. This allows the use to focus on more distant relationships.
This allow one to skip over close relationships in searches for more distant relationships.
'+5/-4' are the default values for nucleotid match/mismatch, but '+3/-2' can perform better in some cases.
Particularly useful for fast[xy], where termination codons are encoded as 'X'.

Set the band-width used for optimization. -y 16 is the default for protein when ktup=2 and for all DNA alignments. -y 32 is used for protein and ktup=1. For proteins, optimization slows comparison 2-fold and is highly recommended.
Force Smith-Waterman alignment for output. Smith-Waterman is the default for protein sequences and FASTX, but not for TFASTA or DNA comparisons with FASTA.
Turn off default optimization of all scores greater than OPTCUT. Shirt results by 'initn' scores reduces the accuracy of statistical estimates. This was the behavior of fasta1 versions.
In general, 1 and 2 are the best methods.
This doubles the time required for a search, but allows accurate statistics to be estimated for libraries comprised of a single protein family.
(MARKX) =0,1,2,3,4. Alternate display of matches and mismatches in alignments.
MARKX=0 uses ':','.',' ', for identities, conservative replacements, and non-conservative replacements, respectively.
MARKX=1 uses ' ','x', and 'X'.

MARKX=2 does not show the second sequence, but uses the second alignment line to display matches with a '.' for identity, or with the mismatched residue for mismatches. MARKX=2 is useful for aligning large numbers of similar sequences.

MARKX=3 writes out a file of library sequences in FASTA format. MARKX=3 should always be used with the 'SHOWALL' (-a) option, but this does not completely ensure that all of the sequences output will be aligned.
MARKX=4 displays a graph of the alignment of the library sequence with respect to the query sequence, so that one can identify the regions of the query sequence that are conserved.
Causes fasta/lfasta/plfasta to start numbering the aligned sequences starting with offset1 and offset2, rather than 1 and 1. This is particularly useful for showing alignments of promoter regions.

Treat lower-case characters in the query or library sequence as 'low-complexity' residues. These characters are treated as 'X' during the initial scan, but are treated as normal residues during the final alignment. Sinces statistical significance is calculated from similarity score calculated during library search, low complexity regions will not produce statistical significant matches.
If a significant alignment contains low complexity regions the final score may be higher than the score obtained during the search.

comment.text: - fasta: scan a protein or DNA sequence library for similar sequences
- tfasta: compare a protein sequence to a DNA sequence librarSy, translating the DNA sequence library `on-the-fly' to the 3 forward and the 3 reverse frames without frameshifts.
- fastx/fasty: compare a DNA sequence to a protein sequence database, comparing the translated DNA sequence in three frames, with frameshifts. fasty2 allows frameshifts inside codons.
- tfastx/tfasty: compare a protein sequence vs a translated DNA db, with frameshifts. tfasty allows frameshifts inside codons.
- fastf/tfastf: compare an ordered peptide mixture (obtained for example by Edman degradation of a CNBr cleavage) against a protein or translated DNA database.
- fasts/tfasts: compare a set of short peptide fragments (obtained from a mass-spec analysis of a protein) against a protein or translated DNA database.

- fastx/fasty: compare a DNA sequence to a protein sequence database, comparing the translated DNA sequence in three frames, with frameshifts. fasty2 allows frameshifts inside codons.
- tfastx/tfasty: compare a protein sequence vs a translated DNA db, with frameshifts. tfasty allows frameshifts inside codons.

parameter.name: query
parameter.prompt: Query sequence File

parameter.name: seqtype
parameter.prompt: Is it a DNA or protein sequence (-n)

format.code: ( "" , " -n" )[ value is not None and value == "DNA" and fasta == 'fasta']

message.text: fastf, fasts, tfasta, tfastx, tfasty, tfastf and tfasts take a protein sequence
fastx and fasty take a DNA sequence

ctrl.code: (seqtype == "protein" and fasta in ["fasta", "fastf", "fasts", "tfasta", "tfastx", "tfasty", "tfastf", "tfasts"]) or (seqtype == "DNA" and fasta in ["fasta", "fastx", "fasty"] )

parameter.name: break_long
parameter.prompt: Break long library sequences into blocks (-N)

comment.text: Break long library sequences into blocks of N residues. Useful for bacterial genomes, which have only one sequence entry. -N 2000 works well for well for bacterial genomes.

interface.label:
Break long library sequences into blocks (-N)?
Break long library sequences into blocks of N residues. Useful for bacterial genomes, which have only one sequence entry. -N 2000 works well for well for bacterial genomes.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Break long library sequences into blocks of N residues. Useful for bacterial genomes, which have only one sequence entry. -N 2000 works well for well for bacterial genomes.

parameter.name: ktup
parameter.prompt: Sensitivity and speed of the search

message.text: ktup can be set to 2 or 1 for protein sequences or from 1 to 6 for DNA sequences.

ctrl.code: ($seqtype eq "protein" and ($value == 1 or $value == 2 )) or ($seqtype eq "DNA" and ($value == 1 or $value == 2 or $value == 3 or $value == 4 or $value == 5 or $value == 6 )))
(seqtype == "protein" and value in [1,2]) or (seqtype == "DNA" and value in range(1,7,1))

comment.text: ktup sets the sensitivity and speed of the search. If ktup=2, similar regions in the two sequences being compared are found by looking at pairs of aligned residues; if ktup=1, single aligned amino acids are examined. ktup can be set to 2 or 1 for protein sequences, or from 1 to 6 for DNA sequences. The default if ktup is not specified is 2 for proteins and 6 for DNA. 1ktup=1 should be used for oligonucleotides (DNA query length < 20).

interface.label:
Sensitivity and speed of the search ?
ktup sets the sensitivity and speed of the search. If ktup=2, similar regions in the two sequences being compared are found by looking at pairs of aligned residues; if ktup=1, single aligned amino acids are examined. ktup can be set to 2 or 1 for protein sequences, or from 1 to 6 for DNA sequences. The default if ktup is not specified is 2 for proteins and 6 for DNA. 1ktup=1 should be used for oligonucleotides (DNA query length < 20).

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: ktup sets the sensitivity and speed of the search. If ktup=2, similar regions in the two sequences being compared are found by looking at pairs of aligned residues; if ktup=1, single aligned amino acids are examined. ktup can be set to 2 or 1 for protein sequences, or from 1 to 6 for DNA sequences. The default if ktup is not specified is 2 for proteins and 6 for DNA. 1ktup=1 should be used for oligonucleotides (DNA query length < 20).

The default for fastx/fasty/tfastz/tfasty is -15.

parameter.name: gapext
parameter.prompt: Penalty for gap extension (-g)

comment.text: The default for fasta is -2 for proteins and -4 for DNA
The default for fastx/fasty/tfastz/tfasty is -3.

interface.label:
Penalty for gap extension (-g)?
The default for fasta is -2 for proteins and -4 for DNA
The default for fastx/fasty/tfastz/tfasty is -3.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The default for fasta is -2 for proteins and -4 for DNA
The default for fastx/fasty/tfastz/tfasty is -3.

parameter.name: high_expect
parameter.prompt: Maximal expectation value threshold for displaying scores and alignments (-E)

format.code: ("" , " -E " + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Expectation value limit for displaying scores and alignments. Defaults are 10.0 for FASTA protein searches, 5.0 for translated DNA/protein comparisons, and 2.0 for DNA/DNA searches.

interface.label:
Maximal expectation value threshold for displaying scores and alignments (-E)?
Expectation value limit for displaying scores and alignments. Defaults are 10.0 for FASTA protein searches, 5.0 for translated DNA/protein comparisons, and 2.0 for DNA/DNA searches.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Expectation value limit for displaying scores and alignments. Defaults are 10.0 for FASTA protein searches, 5.0 for translated DNA/protein comparisons, and 2.0 for DNA/DNA searches.

parameter.name: low_expect
parameter.prompt: Minimal expectation value threshold for displaying scores and alignments (-F)

comment.text: Expectation value lower limit for score and alignment display. If value is 1e-6 prevents library sequences with E()-values lower than 1e-6 from being displayed. This allows the use to focus on more distant relationships.
This allow one to skip over close relationships in searches for more distant relationships.

interface.label:
Minimal expectation value threshold for displaying scores and alignments (-F)?
Expectation value lower limit for score and alignment display. If value is 1e-6 prevents library sequences with E()-values lower than 1e-6 from being displayed. This allows the use to focus on more distant relationships.
This allow one to skip over close relationships in searches for more distant relationships.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Expectation value lower limit for score and alignment display. If value is 1e-6 prevents library sequences with E()-values lower than 1e-6 from being displayed. This allows the use to focus on more distant relationships.
This allow one to skip over close relationships in searches for more distant relationships.

parameter.name: nucleotid_match
parameter.prompt: Maximum positive value for a nucleotid match (-r)

interface.label: Maximum positive value for a nucleotid match (-r)

parameter.name: nucleotid_mismatch
parameter.prompt: Maximum negative penalty value for a nucleotid mismatch (-r)

format.code: ( "" , ' -r "' + str(nucleotid_match) + '/' + str(value)+ '"' )[ value is not None and nucleotid_match is not None and (nucleotid_match != 5 and value != vdef) ]

comment.text: '+5/-4' are the default values for nucleotid match/mismatch, but '+3/-2' can perform better in some cases.

interface.label:
Maximum negative penalty value for a nucleotid mismatch (-r)?
'+5/-4' are the default values for nucleotid match/mismatch, but '+3/-2' can perform better in some cases.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: '+5/-4' are the default values for nucleotid match/mismatch, but '+3/-2' can perform better in some cases.

parameter.name: matrix
parameter.prompt: Scoring matrix file (-s)

format.code: ( "" , " -s " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Scoring matrix file (-s) BLOSUM50 BLOSUM62 BLOSUM80 PAM20 PAM40 PAM120 PAM250 MDM_10 MDM_20 MDM_40

parameter.name: X_penalty
parameter.prompt: Penalty for a match to 'X' (independently of the PAM matrix) (-x)

comment.text: Particularly useful for fast[xy], where termination codons are encoded as 'X'.

interface.label:
Penalty for a match to 'X' (independently of the PAM matrix) (-x)?
Particularly useful for fast[xy], where termination codons are encoded as 'X'.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Particularly useful for fast[xy], where termination codons are encoded as 'X'.

parameter.name: frameshift
parameter.prompt: Penalty for frameshift between two codons (fast[xy]/tfast[xy]) (-h)

interface.label: Penalty for frameshift between two codons (fast[xy]/tfast[xy]) (-h)

parameter.name: frameshift_within
parameter.prompt: Penalty for frameshift within a codon (fasty/tfasty) (-j)

interface.label: Penalty for frameshift within a codon (fasty/tfasty) (-j)

parameter.name: threeframe
parameter.prompt: Search only the three forward frames (-3)

interface.label: Search only the three forward frames (-3) Yes No

parameter.name: invert
parameter.prompt: Reverse complement the query sequence (-i)

interface.label: Reverse complement the query sequence (-i) Yes No

parameter.name: genetic_code
parameter.prompt: Use genetic code for translation (tfasta/tfast[xy]/fast[xy]) (-t)

velem.label: Mold, Protozoan, Coelenterate Mitochondrial and Mycoplasma/Spiroplasma (3)

format.code: ( "" , " -t " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Use genetic code for translation (tfasta/tfast[xy]/fast[xy]) (-t) Standard (1) Vertebrate Mitochondrial (1) Yeast Mitochondrial (2) Mold, Protozoan, Coelenterate Mitochondrial and Mycoplasma/Spiroplasma (3) Invertebrate Mitochondrial (4) Ciliate Macronuclear and Dasycladacean (5) Echinoderm Mitochondrial (6) Euplotid Nuclear (7) Bacterial (8) Alternative Yeast Nuclear (9) Ascidian Mitochondrial (10) Flatworm Mitochondrial (11) Blepharisma Macronuclear (12)

parameter.name: band
parameter.prompt: Band-width used for optimization (-y)

comment.text: Set the band-width used for optimization. -y 16 is the default for protein when ktup=2 and for all DNA alignments. -y 32 is used for protein and ktup=1. For proteins, optimization slows comparison 2-fold and is highly recommended.

interface.label:
Band-width used for optimization (-y)?
Set the band-width used for optimization. -y 16 is the default for protein when ktup=2 and for all DNA alignments. -y 32 is used for protein and ktup=1. For proteins, optimization slows comparison 2-fold and is highly recommended.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the band-width used for optimization. -y 16 is the default for protein when ktup=2 and for all DNA alignments. -y 32 is used for protein and ktup=1. For proteins, optimization slows comparison 2-fold and is highly recommended.

parameter.name: swalig
parameter.prompt: Force Smith-Waterman alignment for DNA (-A)

comment.text: Force Smith-Waterman alignment for output. Smith-Waterman is the default for protein sequences and FASTX, but not for TFASTA or DNA comparisons with FASTA.

interface.label:
Force Smith-Waterman alignment for DNA (-A)?
Yes No
Force Smith-Waterman alignment for output. Smith-Waterman is the default for protein sequences and FASTX, but not for TFASTA or DNA comparisons with FASTA.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Force Smith-Waterman alignment for output. Smith-Waterman is the default for protein sequences and FASTX, but not for TFASTA or DNA comparisons with FASTA.

parameter.name: noopt
parameter.prompt: Turn fasta band optimization off during initial phase (-o)

comment.text: Turn off default optimization of all scores greater than OPTCUT. Shirt results by 'initn' scores reduces the accuracy of statistical estimates. This was the behavior of fasta1 versions.

interface.label:
Turn fasta band optimization off during initial phase (-o)?
Yes No
Turn off default optimization of all scores greater than OPTCUT. Shirt results by 'initn' scores reduces the accuracy of statistical estimates. This was the behavior of fasta1 versions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Turn off default optimization of all scores greater than OPTCUT. Shirt results by 'initn' scores reduces the accuracy of statistical estimates. This was the behavior of fasta1 versions.

parameter.name: stat
parameter.prompt: Specify statistical calculation. (-z)

velem.label: Weigthed regression against the length of the library sequence (1)
Maximum likelihood estimates of Lambda abd K (2)
Maximum likelihood estimate based on the method of Mott (6)

format.code: ( (( "", " -z " + str(value) ) [ value is not None and value != vdef]) , " -z 1" + str(value) )[value is not None and value > 0 and random is not None ]

comment.text: In general, 1 and 2 are the best methods.

interface.label:
Specify statistical calculation. (-z)?
Turn off statistics (0) Weigthed regression against the length of the library sequence (1) Maximum likelihood estimates of Lambda abd K (2) Altschul-Gishas statistical (3) Alternate regression method: Variation 1 of 1 (4) Alternate regression method: Variation 2 of 1 (5) Maximum likelihood estimate based on the method of Mott (6)
In general, 1 and 2 are the best methods.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: In general, 1 and 2 are the best methods.

parameter.name: random
parameter.prompt: Estimate statistical parameters from shuffled copies of each library sequence (-z)

comment.text: This doubles the time required for a search, but allows accurate statistics to be estimated for libraries comprised of a single protein family.

interface.label:
Estimate statistical parameters from shuffled copies of each library sequence (-z)?
Yes No
This doubles the time required for a search, but allows accurate statistics to be estimated for libraries comprised of a single protein family.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This doubles the time required for a search, but allows accurate statistics to be estimated for libraries comprised of a single protein family.

parameter.name: histogram
parameter.prompt: Turn off histogram display (-H)

interface.label: Turn off histogram display (-H) Yes No

parameter.name: scores
parameter.prompt: Number of similarity scores to be shown (-b)

format.code: ("" , " -b " + str(value))[ value is not None and value <= high_expect]

message.text: Must be <= -E cutoff if -E is given.

interface.label: Number of similarity scores to be shown (-b)

parameter.name: alns
parameter.prompt: Number of alignments to be shown (-d)

format.code: ("" , " -d " + str(value))[ value is not None and value <= high_expect]

message.text: Must be <= -E cutoff if -E is given.

interface.label: Number of alignments to be shown (-d)

parameter.name: html_output
parameter.prompt: HTML output (-m)

interface.label: HTML output (-m) Yes No

parameter.name: markx
parameter.prompt: Alternate display of matches and mismatches in alignments (-m)

velem.label: 2: [. identities] [res mismatch] - don't display the 2nd seq
3: writes a file of library sequences in FASTA format
4: displays a graph of the alignment

format.code: ( "" , " -m " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: (MARKX) =0,1,2,3,4. Alternate display of matches and mismatches in alignments.
MARKX=0 uses ':','.',' ', for identities, conservative replacements, and non-conservative replacements, respectively.
MARKX=1 uses ' ','x', and 'X'.

MARKX=2 does not show the second sequence, but uses the second alignment line to display matches with a '.' for identity, or with the mismatched residue for mismatches. MARKX=2 is useful for aligning large numbers of similar sequences.

MARKX=3 writes out a file of library sequences in FASTA format. MARKX=3 should always be used with the 'SHOWALL' (-a) option, but this does not completely ensure that all of the sequences output will be aligned.
MARKX=4 displays a graph of the alignment of the library sequence with respect to the query sequence, so that one can identify the regions of the query sequence that are conserved.

interface.label:
Alternate display of matches and mismatches in alignments (-m)?
0 [: identities] [. conservative repl] [ non-conserv repl] 1: [ identities] [x conservative repl] [X non-conserv repl] 2: [. identities] [res mismatch] - don't display the 2nd seq 3: writes a file of library sequences in FASTA format 4: displays a graph of the alignment 9: 0 + percent identity + coordinates 10: output more information
(MARKX) =0,1,2,3,4. Alternate display of matches and mismatches in alignments.
MARKX=0 uses ':','.',' ', for identities, conservative replacements, and non-conservative replacements, respectively.
MARKX=1 uses ' ','x', and 'X'.
MARKX=2 does not show the second sequence, but uses the second alignment line to display matches with a '.' for identity, or with the mismatched residue for mismatches. MARKX=2 is useful for aligning large numbers of similar sequences.
MARKX=3 writes out a file of library sequences in FASTA format. MARKX=3 should always be used with the 'SHOWALL' (-a) option, but this does not completely ensure that all of the sequences output will be aligned.
MARKX=4 displays a graph of the alignment of the library sequence with respect to the query sequence, so that one can identify the regions of the query sequence that are conserved.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: (MARKX) =0,1,2,3,4. Alternate display of matches and mismatches in alignments.
MARKX=0 uses ':','.',' ', for identities, conservative replacements, and non-conservative replacements, respectively.
MARKX=1 uses ' ','x', and 'X'.

MARKX=2 does not show the second sequence, but uses the second alignment line to display matches with a '.' for identity, or with the mismatched residue for mismatches. MARKX=2 is useful for aligning large numbers of similar sequences.

MARKX=3 writes out a file of library sequences in FASTA format. MARKX=3 should always be used with the 'SHOWALL' (-a) option, but this does not completely ensure that all of the sequences output will be aligned.
MARKX=4 displays a graph of the alignment of the library sequence with respect to the query sequence, so that one can identify the regions of the query sequence that are conserved.

parameter.name: init1
parameter.prompt: Sequences ranked by the z-score based on the init1 score (-1)

interface.label: Sequences ranked by the z-score based on the init1 score (-1) Yes No

parameter.name: z_score_out
parameter.prompt: Show normalize score as (-B)

format.code: ( "" , " -B" )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Show normalize score as (-B) z-score (1) bit-score (0)

parameter.name: linlen
parameter.prompt: Output line length for sequence alignments (-w)

format.code: ("" , " -w " + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

interface.label: Output line length for sequence alignments (-w)

parameter.name: offsets
parameter.prompt: Start numbering the aligned sequences at position x1 x2 (2 numbers separated by comma) (-X)

message.text: Must be 2 numbers separated by comma.

comment.text: Causes fasta/lfasta/plfasta to start numbering the aligned sequences starting with offset1 and offset2, rather than 1 and 1. This is particularly useful for showing alignments of promoter regions.

interface.label:
Start numbering the aligned sequences at position x1 x2 (2 numbers separated by comma) (-X)?
Causes fasta/lfasta/plfasta to start numbering the aligned sequences starting with offset1 and offset2, rather than 1 and 1. This is particularly useful for showing alignments of promoter regions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Causes fasta/lfasta/plfasta to start numbering the aligned sequences starting with offset1 and offset2, rather than 1 and 1. This is particularly useful for showing alignments of promoter regions.

parameter.name: info
parameter.prompt: Display more information about the library sequence in the alignment (-L)

interface.label: Display more information about the library sequence in the alignment (-L) Yes No

parameter.name: filter
parameter.prompt: Lower case filtering (-S)

comment.text: Treat lower-case characters in the query or library sequence as 'low-complexity' residues. These characters are treated as 'X' during the initial scan, but are treated as normal residues during the final alignment. Sinces statistical significance is calculated from similarity score calculated during library search, low complexity regions will not produce statistical significant matches.
If a significant alignment contains low complexity regions the final score may be higher than the score obtained during the search.

interface.label:
Lower case filtering (-S)?
Yes No
Treat lower-case characters in the query or library sequence as 'low-complexity' residues. These characters are treated as 'X' during the initial scan, but are treated as normal residues during the final alignment. Sinces statistical significance is calculated from similarity score calculated during library search, low complexity regions will not produce statistical significant matches.
If a significant alignment contains low complexity regions the final score may be higher than the score obtained during the search.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Treat lower-case characters in the query or library sequence as 'low-complexity' residues. These characters are treated as 'X' during the initial scan, but are treated as normal residues during the final alignment. Sinces statistical significance is calculated from similarity score calculated during library search, low complexity regions will not produce statistical significant matches.
If a significant alignment contains low complexity regions the final score may be higher than the score obtained during the search.

parameter.prompt: Fasta report

parameter.prompt: Html output file
